arch:property.oc:show_val: Located in northwest quadrant of trench. Adult individual, possibly female, in an extended position on his/her back with head on the eastern side of the locus facing north and the body going west toward the west baulk. Only half of the body is present/preserved from the base of the rib cage to the skull. One arm is bent at the elbow with hand resting on the corresponding collarbone/shoulder. At least the skull is resting on a burn layer and/or surface which possibly extended to include the entire body resting on this surface. This burn layer is also visible in the north section profile of this locus.
poorly sorted angular clay in a silt matrix

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area F / Trench 7 / Locus 7148 (Locus)
